introduction.p: You may save your work at any time by clicking on Save. When you are finished working, click on Submit and Finish, a pop up window will ask "This will submit your answers and finish this assignment. Are you sure?", click "OK" if you are ready to submit your answers for final grading.
If you close this window without having saved or submitted, your changes will be lost. After pressing Submit and Finish, please wait for your answers to be scored. Do NOT click on it more than once.

body.p: The histogram below displays the distribution of 50 ages at death due to trauma (accidents and homicides) that were observed in a certain hospital during a week.
What percentage of deaths were individuals younger than 35?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It is true that 3 + 18 + 13 = 34 out of the 50 fall below age 35 (those within the first three bars). However, note that the problem asks for percentage rather than count.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 35 (i.e., within the first three bars), the percentage is actually higher than 60%. Count the number of observations below 35 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

Correct. From the histogram we can ﬁnd that 3 + 18 + 13 = 34 out of the 50 observations fall below age 35 (those within the first three bars), and since the question asks about the percentage of observations, the answer is (34/50) * 100 = 68%.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 35 (those within the first three bars), the percentage is actually lower than 70%. Count the number of observations below 35 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 35 (those within the first three bars), this is not quite as high as 80%. Count the number of observations below 35 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

body.p: The histogram below displays the distribution of 50 ages at death due to trauma (accidents and homicides) that were observed in a certain hospital during a week.
Which of the following best describes the shape of the histogram?

input.choice: Symmetric
Left-skewed with no outliers
Right-skewed with no outliers
Left-skewed with a possible outlier
Right-skewed with a possible outlier

response.feedback: Incorrect. The shape of the distribution is clearly skewed. Where is the “tail,” and are there any possible outliers?

Incorrect. While it is true that the distribution is skewed, recall that the direction of the skewness is determined by where the “tail” is. Also, look at the distribution carefully. Are there any possible outliers?
Incorrect. You are correct that the distribution is skewed right, however note that one of the other answers more accurately describes the distribution.
Incorrect. While it is true that the distribution is skewed, recall that the direction of the skewness is determined by where the “tail” is.
Correct. The distribution of ages is skewed right (which is where the “tail” of the distribution is). Also the largest observation—approximately equal to 90—is a possible high outlier.

body.p: The histogram below displays the distribution of 50 ages at death due to trauma (accidents and homicides) that were observed in a certain hospital during a week.
For the data described by the above histogram, which of the following is a correct statement about the median?

input.choice: The median will be bigger than the mean.
The median will be smaller than the mean.
The median and the mean will be about the same.
The median and the range will be about the same.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Notice this distribution is skewed to the right (the tail is towardthe right), and we also see a suspected outlier on the right side. Remember that both of these shape features will tend to “pull” the mean more than they would pull the median.

Correct. The mean is more sensitive than the median to the “tail” of a distribution, and also to outliers. We see that this distribution is skewed to the right (the tail is towards the right) and we also see a suspected outlier on the right side. Both of these shape features will tend to “pull” the mean toward the tail more than they would pull the median, meaning that the median will be smaller than the mean.

Incorrect. Remember that we would expect the mean and the median to be nearly the same only if the distribution was nearly symmetric. But notice this distribution is skewed to the right (the tail is towards the right) and we also see a suspected outlier on the right side. Remember that both of these shape features will tend to “pull” the mean more than they would pull the median.

Incorrect. Remember that the range is the length from lowest value to highest value. So, for this distribution, the range is approximately 80. But remember that the median is the middle value. Half the people must be older than the median, so the median will be much less than 80, because all but one of the people were younger than 80.

body.p: The histogram below displays the distribution of 50 ages at death due to trauma (accidents and homicides) that occurred in a certain hospital during a week.
Which of the following is a possible value of the median in this example?

input.choice: It is impossible to answer without seeing all of the data.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that the median is the middle value. Only 21 people out of 50 could be younger than age 23, as represented by the total height of the two left bars on the display. So 23 is too low to be the median.

Incorrect. Remember that the median is the middle value. Only 10 people out of 50 could be older than age 45, as represented by the total height of the four bars on the right side of the display. So 45 is too large to be the median.

Incorrect. Remember that the median is the value of the middle person, not the middle of the range. Only 10 people out of 50 could be older than age 50, as represented by the total height of the four bars on the right side of the display. So 50 is too large to be the median.

Correct. The median is the middle value. There are 50 people in the data, so the median must be the age between the 25th youngest person and the 26th youngest person. These people will both be represented in the third bar from the left on the display. Since that bar represents ages from 25 to 35, the median could be any value between those ages.

body.p: The histogram below displays the distribution of 50 ages at death due to trauma (accidents and homicides) that were observed in a certain hospital during a week.
Assume that the largest observation in this dataset is 90. If this observation were wrongly recorded as 900, then what would happen to the mean and median?

input.choice: Neither the mean nor the median would change.
Both the mean and the median would change.
The mean would stay the same, but the median would change.
The mean would decrease, but the median would not change.
The mean would increase, but the median would not change.

response.feedback: Incorrect. It is true that the median would not change, because pulling 90 to 900 would not change the 25th or the 26th value in the data. But remember that the mean tends to be “pulled” by an outlier. So moving the largest value, 90, farther to the right, to 900, would tend to pull the mean to the right, making it larger.

Incorrect. It is true that the mean would change, because mean tends to be “pulled” by outliers. But remember that the median is the middle value. Moving 90 to 900 would not change the 25th or the 26th value in the data, so the median would be the same.

Incorrect. Remember that the mean tends to be “pulled” by an outlier. So moving the largest value, 90, farther to the right, to 900, would tend to pull the mean to the right. So the mean would change. But the median is the middle value. Pulling 90 to 900 would not change the 25th or the 26th value in the data, so the median would be the same.

Incorrect. It is true that the median would not change, because moving 90 to 900 would not change the 25th or the 26th value in the data. But remember that the mean tends to be “pulled” by an outlier. Moving the largest value, 90, farther to the right, to 900, would tend to pull the mean to the right, making it increase, not decrease.

Correct. The mean will increase, because the mean tends to be “pulled” by an outlier. So moving the largest value, 90, farther to the right, to 900, would tend to pull the mean to the right. The median would not be affected, because moving 90 to 900 would not change the 25th or the 26th value in the data.

body.p: The following data, on the number of children born per 1,000 women, is from the Current Population Reports—Fertility of American Women: 2008
What is the modal number of children born to American women in 2008?

response.feedback: Correct. The most commonly occurring value is 0; therefore, 0 is the modal number of children born to American women, in 2008.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The third-most frequently occurring value is 1.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The second-most frequently occurring value is 2.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The fourth-most frequently occurring value is 3.

body.p: This histogram shows the times, in minutes, required for 25 rats in an animal behavior experiment to successfully navigate a maze.
What percentage of the rats navigated the maze in less than 5.5 minutes?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It is true that 3 + 8 + 6 + 4 = 21 out of the 25 rats fall below 5.5 minutes (first four bars). However, the question asks about the percentage of observations rather than the count.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 5.5 minutes (i.e., within the first four bars), the percentage is actually higher than 60%. Count the number of observations below 5.5 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 5.5 minutes (i.e., within the first four bars), the percentage is actually higher than 60%. Count the number of observations below 5.5 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

Incorrect. While it is clear from looking at the histogram that more than 50% of the observations fall below 5.5 minutes (i.e., within the first four bars), the percentage is actually higher than 70%. Count the number of observations below 5.5 and then use that number to calculate the percentage.

Correct. From the histogram we can find that 3 + 8 + 6 + 4 = 21 out of the 25 rats fall below 5.5 minutes (first four bars). Since the question asks about the percentage of observations, the answer is 21/25 * 100 = 84%.

body.p: This histogram shows the times, in minutes, required for 25 rats in an animal behavior experiment to successfully navigate a maze.
Which of the following best describes the shape of the histogram?

input.choice: Symmetric
Left-skewed with no outliers
Right-skewed with no outliers
Left-skewed with a possible outlier
Right-skewed with a possible outlier

response.feedback: Incorrect. The shape of the distribution is clearly skewed. Where is the tail, and are there any possible outliers?

Incorrect. While it is true that the distribution is skewed, recall that the direction of the skewness is determined by where the tail is. Also, look at the distribution carefully. Are there any possible outliers?
Incorrect. You are correct that the distribution is skewed right. However, note that one of the other answers more accurately describes the distribution.
Incorrect. While it is true that the distribution is skewed, recall that the direction of the skewness is determined by where the tail is.
Correct. The distribution of times is skewed right (which is where the tail of the distribution is). Also, the largest observation—approximately equal to 9 minutes—is a possible high outlier.

body.p: This histogram shows the times, in minutes, required for 25 rats in an animal behavior experiment to successfully navigate a maze.
For the data described by the above histogram, which of the following is a correct statement about the median?

input.choice: The median will be smaller than the mean.
The median will be larger than the mean.
The median and the mean will be about the same.
The median and the range will be about the same.

response.feedback: Correct. When the distribution is skewed right, the mean is “pulled up” by the large observations in the “tail” of the distribution. The median, on the other hand, is only determined by the order of the observations, and is not affected by their magnitude. Therefore, in this case, the median is smaller than the mean.

Incorrect. When the distribution is skewed right, the mean is “pulled up” by the large observations in the “tail” of the distribution. The median, on the other hand, is only determined by the order of the observations, and is not affected by their magnitude.

Incorrect. When the distribution is skewed right, the mean is “pulled up” by the large observations in the “tail” of the distribution. The median, on the other hand, is only determined by the order of the observations, and is not affected by their magnitude..

Incorrect. Remember that the range is the length from lowest value to highest value. So, for this distribution, the range is approximately 7. But remember that the median is the middle value. Half of the times must be greater than the median, so the median will be much less than 7, because all but two of the times were less than 7.

body.p: This histogram shows the times, in minutes, required for 25 rats in an animal behavior experiment to successfully navigate a maze.
Which of the following is a possible value of the median in this example?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that the median is the middle value. There are 25 observations (odd number) and therefore the median is the 13th ranked observation. Only 11 observations fall below 3.5, so 3.3 is too low to be the median.

Correct. There are 25 observations (odd number), and therefore the median is the 13th ranked observation. If we look at the histogram, we can figure out that the 13th observation falls in the third interval (3.5–4.5 minutes). The only option with such a number is 3.9 minutes.

Incorrect. Remember that the median is the middle value. There are 25 observations (odd number) and therefore the median is the 13th ranked observation. Only 8 observations fall above 4.5, so 4.6 is too high to be the median.

Incorrect. Remember that the median is the middle value. There are 25 observations (odd number) and therefore the median is the 13th ranked observation. Only 5 observations fall above 5.5, so this is too high to be the median.

body.p: This histogram shows the times, in minutes, required for 25 rats in an animal behavior experiment to successfully navigate a maze.
Assume that the largest observation in this dataset is 8.6 minutes. If this observation were wrongly recorded as 86, then what would happen to the mean and median?

input.choice: Neither the mean nor the median would change.
Both the mean and the median would change.
The mean would stay the same, but the median would change.
The mean would decrease, but the median would not change.
The mean would increase, but the median would not change.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The mean is affected by the actual values of the observations, whereas the median is determined by their order. While the median would stay the same, changing the largest observation from 8.6 to 86 would have an impact on the mean.

Incorrect. The mean is affected by the actual values of the observations, whereas the median is determined by their order. Therefore, changing the largest observation from 8.6 to 86 would have an impact on the mean. However, the median would stay the same.

Incorrect. It appears you confused the impact of an outlier on the mean and median. The mean is affected by the actual values of the observations, whereas the median is determined by their order. Therefore, changing the largest observation from 8.6 to 86 would have an impact on the mean, while the median would stay the same.

Incorrect. The mean is affected by the actual values of the observations, whereas the median is determined by their order. While the median would stay the same, changing the largest observation from 8.6 to 86 would have an impact on the mean. But remember that the mean tends to be “pulled” by an outlier. Moving the largest value, 8.6, farther to the right, to 86, would tend to pull the mean to the right, making it increase, not decrease.

feedback.p: Correct. The mean is affected by the actual values of the observations, whereas the median is determined by their order. Therefore, changing the largest observation from 8.6 to 86 would have an impact on the mean, while the median would stay the same. So moving the largest value, 8.6, farther to the right, to 86, would tend to pull the mean to the right. The median would not be affected, because moving 8.6 t o 86 would not change the 13th value in the data.

Actually, we can figure out the exact impact that the change will have on the mean: By changing 8.6 to 86, the sum of all the observations is increased by 86 - 8.6 = 77.4, and therefore the mean of the 25 observations is increased by 77.4 / 25 = 3.1 minutes.

body.p: A survey was conducted to determine the number of servings of vegetables eaten, per day, by adolescents in the United States. The following table shows the results:
What is the modal number of vegetable servings eaten, per day, by adolescents in the United States?

input.choice: More than 3

response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The least frequently occurring value is 0.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The second-most frequently occurring value is 1.
Correct. The most commonly occurring value is two; therefore, 2 is the modal number of vegetable servings consumed, per day, by U.S. teenagers.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. The fourth-most frequently occurring value is 3.
Incorrect. Remember that the mode is the most frequently occurring value. “More than 3” is the third-most frequently occurring value.
